title: Enrico Francisci
text:
Enrico Francisci (<a href="Montemurlo">Montemurlo</a>, 1884 – <a href="Campobello%20di%20Licata">Campobello di Licata</a>, 11 July 1943) was an Italian <a href="Blackshirt">Blackshirt</a> general during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Biography.
Born in Montemurlo in 1884, Francisci pursued a military career in the <a href="Royal%20Italian%20Army">Royal Italian Army</a>; he fought in <a href="Libya">Libya</a> during the <a href="Italo-Turkish%20War">Italo-Turkish War</a> with the rank of <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in 83rd Infantry Regiment "Venezia", and then participated in the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, earning a <a href="Silver%20Medal%20of%20Military%20Valour">Silver Medal of Military Valour</a>, three <a href="Bronze%20Medal%20of%20Military%20Valour">Bronze Medals of Military Valour</a>, three <a href="War%20Cross%20for%20Military%20Valor">War Crosses for Military Valor</a> and a <a href="War%20Merit%20Cross%20%28Italy%29">War Merit Cross</a>. By the end of the war he had reached the rank of <a href="major">major</a>.
After promotion to <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a> he was attached to the Governorate of <a href="Libya">Libya</a>; he joined <a href="Fascism">Fascism</a> in 1920 and after the <a href="march%20on%20Rome">march on Rome</a> he passed from the Royal Army to the <a href="Blackshirts">Voluntary Militia for National Security</a> with the rank of "console" (colonel), holding command of the 62nd Blackshirt Legion "Isonzo" in <a href="Gorizia">Gorizia</a> and then of the 90th Legion in <a href="Pisa">Pisa</a>.
During the <a href="Second%20Italo-Ethiopian%20War">Second Italo-Ethiopian War</a> he commanded the 135th Blackshirt Legion "Indomita" of the <a href="1st%20Blackshirt%20Division%2023%20Marzo">1st Blackshirt Division 23 Marzo</a>, and was awarded another Silver Medal for Military Valor for his role in the <a href="battle%20of%20Amba%20Aradam">battle of Amba Aradam</a>.
After promotion to "console generale" (<a href="brigadier%20general">brigadier general</a>), he participated in the <a href="Spanish%20Civil%20War">Spanish Civil War</a> in the ranks of the <a href="Corpo%20Truppe%20Volontarie">Corpo Truppe Volontarie</a>, commanding the <a href="XXIII%20de%20Marzo%20Group">"23 Marzo" Blackshirt Group</a>, and in September 1937 he fought in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Santander">Battle of Santander</a> and was promoted to "luogotenente generale" (<a href="major%20general">major general</a>) for war merits.
He left active service in 1939, due to age limits, but returned to the MVSN after the outbreak of the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>; in July 1942 he was given command of the Raggruppamento CC. NN. "23 Marzo", consisting of six Blackshirt battalions, attached to the <a href="Eighth%20Army%20%28Italy%29">8th Army</a> deployed on the <a href="Eastern%20Front%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Eastern Front</a>. In September 1942 his troops repelled a Soviet attack on the <a href="Don%20River">Don River</a>, and in November Francisci was wounded and repatriated. He was then appointed Inspector General of the MVSN of the Armed Forces Command of <a href="Sicily">Sicily</a>.
On 10 July 1943, after <a href="Operation%20Husky">the Allied landings in Sicily</a>, Francisci was tasked by General <a href="Alfredo%20Guzzoni">Alfredo Guzzoni</a>, commander of the <a href="Sixth%20Army%20%28Italy%29">6th Army</a>, with coordinating the counterattack against the American force that had landed in <a href="Licata">Licata</a>. At dawn on 11 July, Francisci led a counterattack launched by the 177th <a href="Bersaglieri">Bersaglieri</a> Regiment and the 161st Self-propelled Artillery Group; during the fighting, while standing on a <a href="self-propelled%20gun">self-propelled gun</a>, he was decapitated by a tank shell near Favarotta. He was posthumously awarded the <a href="Gold%20Medal%20of%20Military%20Valour">Gold Medal of Military Valour</a>, and is buried in <a href="Enna">Enna</a>.
